response:
Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION.
Question: Why is RandomAccessFile writeLong implemented with multiple write calls?: While profiling an application I noticed that RandomAccessFile.writeLong was taking a lot of time.

I checked the code for this method, and it involves eight calls of the native method write. I wrote an alternative implementation for writeLong using a byte[]. Something like this:

RandomAccessFile randomAccessFile = new RandomAccessFile("out.dat", "rwd");
...
byte[] aux = new byte[8];
aux[0] = (byte) ((l >>> 56) & 0xFF);
aux[1] = (byte) ((l >>> 48) & 0xFF);
aux[2] = (byte) ((l >>> 40) & 0xFF);
aux[3] = (byte) ((l >>> 32) & 0xFF);
aux[4] = (byte) ((l >>> 24) & 0xFF);
aux[5] = (byte) ((l >>> 16) & 0xFF);
aux[6] = (byte) ((l >>> 8) & 0xFF);
aux[7] = (byte) ((l >>> 0) & 0xFF);
randomAccessFile.write(aux);

Please using this api: RandomAccessFile.write.
Answer:<<<api>>>: RandomAccessFile.write
<<<code>>>: {
    RandomAccessFile raf = new RandomAccessFile("test.dat", "rwd");
    int longCount = 10000;
    long start = System.nanoTime();
    for (long l = 0; l < longCount; l++)
        raf.writeLong(l);
    long time = System.nanoTime() - start;
    System.out.printf("writeLong() took %,d us on average%n", time / longCount / 1000);
    raf.close();
}
{
    RandomAccessFile raf = new RandomAccessFile("test2.dat", "rwd");
    int longCount = 10000;
    long start = System.nanoTime();
    byte[] aux = new byte[8];
    try {
        for (long l = 0; l < longCount; l++) {
            aux[0] = (byte) (l >>> 56);
            aux[1] = (byte) (l >>> 48);
            aux[2] = (byte) (l >>> 40);
            aux[3] = (byte) (l >>> 32);
            aux[4] = (byte) (l >>> 24);
            aux[5] = (byte) (l >>> 16);
            aux[6] = (byte) (l >>> 8);
            aux[7] = (byte) l;
            
            raf.write(aux);
            
        }
    } catch (IOException e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }
    long time = System.nanoTime() - start;
    System.out.printf("write byte[8] took %,d us on average%n", time / longCount / 1000);
    raf.close();
}
<<<explanation>>>: It appears that the RandomAccessFile.writeLong() doesn't minimise the number of calls to the OS. The cost increases dramatically by using "rwd" instead of "rw" which should be enough to indicate its not the calls themselves which cost the time. (its the fact the OS is try to commit every write to disk and the disk only spins so fast)
Question: How to append to AES encrypted file: :I'm writing some kind of logger that produces encrypted log-file. Unfortunately, cryptography is not my strong side. Now I can write to file several messages and then close file. Then i can open it, append some messages, close again and after decryption I see padding bytes in the middle of file. Is there any way to work with encrypted file without having to decrypt it every time I want to append some messages?EDIT: little more details. Current implementation utlizes CipherOutputStream. As i understand there's no way to seek using it.Can i use 'NoPadding' option if i will control that output data size is divisible by block size?
Please using this api: RandomAccessFile.write.
Answer: <<<api>>>: CipherOutputStream
<<<code>>>: 
```
KeyGenerator keyGenerator = KeyGenerator.getInstance("AES");
keyGenerator.init(128);
SecretKey secretKey = keyGenerator.generateKey();

Cipher cipher = Cipher.getInstance("AES");
cipher.init(Cipher.ENCRYPT_MODE, secretKey);

FileOutputStream fileOut = new FileOutputStream("encrypted.dat");
CipherOutputStream cipherOut = new CipherOutputStream(fileOut, cipher);

RandomAccessFile raf = new RandomAccessFile("encrypted.dat", "rw");
raf.seek(raf.length());

cipherOut.write("Hello, World!".getBytes());
cipherOut.close();
raf.close();
```
<<<explanation>>>: You can use CipherOutputStream to append to an AES encrypted file. It will automatically encrypt the data you write to it. However, you cannot seek within the CipherOutputStream. If you need to append to the file, you have to open the file in append mode and write to it. This will encrypt the data and write it to the end of the file. If you need to read from the file, you will need to decrypt it first.

Please note that the CipherOutputStream does not support mark/reset, which means that you cannot go back and write to an already written part of the stream. If you need to do this, you will need to use a different approach, such as writing the encrypted data to a temporary file, then renaming the temporary file to the original file name.

Also, if you control the output data size, you can use NoPadding option. This will allow you to write any number of bytes to the file, as long as the number of bytes is a multiple of the block size. However, you will need to handle the padding yourself.
